message_1:
Calculate the enthalpy change for the reaction: 
2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(g) 

The enthalpy of formation of H₂O is -242 kJ/mol, and the enthalpy of formation of O₂ is 0 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

where ΔH_reaction is the enthalpy change for the reaction, ΔH_f(products) is the sum of the enthalpies of formation of the products, and ΔH_f(reactants) is the sum of the enthalpies of formation of the reactants.

For this reaction, we have:

Reactants: 2H₂(g) and O₂(g)
Products: 2H₂O(g)

ΔH_f(H₂O) = -242 kJ/mol
ΔH_f(O₂) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔH_f(H₂) = 0 kJ/mol (since it is an element in its standard state)

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH_reaction = [2 × (-242 kJ/mol)] - [2 × 0 kJ/mol + 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH_reaction = (-484 kJ) - (0 kJ)

ΔH_reaction = -484 kJ

The enthalpy change for the reaction is -484 kJ.
